title: What to do if you're signalled to pull over by unmarked police car after woman stopped by impostor
text:
News What to do if you're signalled to pull over by unmarked police car after woman stopped by impostor Here's the official advice on what to do if you suspect you're being flagged down by a bogus officer Share Although police cars can be unmarked, the officer must be in uniform in order to carry out a stop (Photo: Cornwall Live) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
It's a nightmare scenario - you're signalled to pull over by an unmarked police car late at night. 
But after coming to a stop, you suspect the man behind the wheel isn't a real police officer. 
You have no idea of his intentions or what he wants from you. 
This scary situation is exactly what happened to Cornish motorist Ebby Tremain. 
She was followed by a silver or blue Vauxhall that had a blue flashing light on the dashboard. 
When she pulled over, she saw a man wearing a hooded top get out of the car and suspected he was not a genuine police officer. 
She drove away and reported it to the police who said she had done the right thing, according to cornwalllive.com . 
Here we look at what you should do if you find yourself in this terrifying scenario. Call 999 if you believe you are being pursued by a fake police car (Photo: Getty) Does an unmarked police car have the power to stop vehicles? 
The answer is yes. But the officer must be wearing uniform in order to carry out the stop. Do the police need a reason to stop me? 
No, they don't need a reason. The police have the power to stop any vehicle and ask for your name and date of birth and to see your driving licence, insurance and MoT documents. These can usually be shown later at a police station. A genuine police officer will have no problem showing you his or her warrant card (Photo: Getty) Read More Crash bride and groom get a lift to their wedding reception in a police car What if I am not sure it is really a police car? 
The advice from Devon and Cornwall Police is that anyone unsure whether the car flashing them is the police, then do not stop. 
Anyone who is not 100% sure it is a genuine police car is advised to drive the nearest police station or public place, such as a petrol station. In remote areas, the driveway of a clearly occupied house could do at a push. The answer is not to stop anywhere secluded. 
If in doubt, call 999. The police can always check if one of their cars is following you. 
Even if you decide not to stop straightaway and have to wait for a safe place to pull over, motorists are advised to signal to the police car that you have acknowledged the request. 
Do not drive off at great speed making the police think you are trying to get away. Read More Driver who was pulled over by police 'SEVENTEEN times in 12 months' What happens when I've stopped? 
Keep the doors locked until you are happy it is the police. Have your mobile at hand just in case. 
You can ask to see a warrant card, which should carry the police officer's name and photograph, through the closed window. 
The advice is always to stay safe and in an emergency, do not hesitate to call 999. Like us on Facebook
